required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety Study of Nicotine Mint Lozenge (2mg and 4mg) in Smoking Cessation
clinical_study.official_title: A Multi-center, Randomized, Double-blind, Parallel, Placebo-controlled Clinical Study to Evaluate Efficacy and Safety of Nicotine Mint Lozenge (2mg and 4mg) in Smoking Cessation

brief_summary.textblock: A multi-center, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, 4-arm clinical study to evaluate efficacy and safety of nicotine lozenge (2mg and 4mg) in smoking cessation in adult cigarette smokers who are motivated to quit smoking. Successful quitters or participants who smoke occasionally will be followed up after week 24 till 12 months.

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 6
primary_outcome.description: Rate of Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 6 was measured by Carbon Monoxide (CO) breath levels.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of Continuous Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 12 and Week 24
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline to Week 12 and Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Continuous abstinence was verified by measurement of CO breath levels.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rate of Long-term Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Rate of long-term successful smoking cessation at Week 24 was defined as the proportion of participants who achieved the primary end-point with no more than six cumulative days of smoking from Week 6 to Week 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of Participants With Seven Day Point Prevalence Abstinence
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Weekly assessment at Week 1, 2, 4, 6, 12 and Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: Seven day point prevalence abstinence was defined as complete abstinence from smoking for the 7 days up to and including the evaluation day.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Score of Relief of Craving/ Total Withdrawal Symptoms
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Weekly assessment at Week 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and Week 6
secondary_outcome.description: The evaluation of withdrawal and craving symptoms was carried out every day with the Minnesota Nicotine Withdrawal scale (MNWS). The MNWS total score contains 9 items (urge to smoke; depressed mood; irritability, frustration, or anger; anxiety; difficulty concentrating; restlessness; increased appetite; difficulty going to sleep; difficulty staying asleep). Each item was rated on a 5 grade scale with scores ranging from 0 (best score) to 4 (worst score) i.e. none (score=0), slight (score=1), mild (score=2), moderate (score=3), and severe (score=4). For each symptom at each week, the average score was calculated as the average of the daily scores during that week. The total score was calculated as the sum of the 9 symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Daily Dose at Visit 4, 5, 6, 7 and 10
secondary_outcome.description: Mean daily dose of lozenges was calculated as number of lozenges taken at each visit divided by days since the last visit.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change From Baseline in Body Weight at Week 6, Week 12 and Week 24/ Premature Termination.
secondary_outcome.description: Change in body weight was analyzed at Weeks 6, 12, and 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs), Serious AEs (SAEs), Cardiovascular AEs and Who Discontinued Due to AEs
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Weekly assessments from first treatment dose up to 15 days after last treatment dose
secondary_outcome.description: All AEs and SAEs were reviewed and reported by investigator. AEs were graded on a 3-point scale as Mild, Moderate and Severe.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited at the clinical site.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Of 781 screened participants, only 723 were randomized and remaining 58 were considered screening failures. Participants who smoked their first cigarette within 30 minutes after waking were considered as high dependence smokers while those who smoked their first cigarette after 30 minutes of waking were considered as low dependence smokers.

group.title: Nicotine Lozenge 2 Milligram (mg) (Low Dependence Smokers)
group.description: Participants who smoked their first cigarette after 30 minutes of waking received 2 mg of nicotine lozenge, orally. During week 1 to week 6,participants were recommended to take at least 9 lozenges per day, but not exceeding 15 lozenges. During week 7 to week 9, participants were recommended to use 12 to 6 lozenges per day, further taking 3 to 6 lozenges only by week 10 to 12. Afterwards, lozenge was taken when necessary to prevent relapse.

group.title: Placebo Lozenge (Low Dependence Smokers)
group.description: Participants who smoked their first cigarette after 30 minutes of waking received placebo lozenge containing 0 mg of nicotine, orally. During week 1 to week 6, participants were recommended to take atleast 9 lozenges per day but not exceeding 15 lozenges. During week 7 to week 9, participants were recommended to use 12 to 6 lozenges per day, further taking 3 to 6 lozenges only by week 10 to 12. Afterwards, lozenge was taken when necessary to prevent relapse

group.title: Nicotine Lozenge 4 mg (High Dependence Smokers)
group.description: Participants who smoked their first cigarette within 30 minutes after waking received 4 mg nicotine lozenge, orally. During week 1 to week 6, participants were recommended to take at least 9 lozenges per day but not exceeding 15 lozenges. During week 7 to week 9, participants were recommended to use 12 to 6 lozenge per day, further taking 3 to 6 lozenges only by week 10 to 12. Afterwards, lozenge was taken when necessary to prevent relapse.

group.title: Placebo Lozenge (High Dependence Smoke
group.description: Participants who smoked their first cigarette within 30 minutes after waking received placebo lozenge containing 0 mg of nicotine, orally. During week 1 to week 6, participants were recommended to take at least 9 lozenges per day but not exceeding 15 lozenges. During week 7 to week 9, participants were recommended to use 12 to 6 lozenge per day, further taking 3 to 6 lozenges only by week 10 to 12. Afterwards, lozenge was taken when necessary to prevent relapse.

participants_list.participants: One participant withdrew consent and was not included as the FAS population.

outcome.title: Rate of Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 6
outcome.description: Rate of Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 6 was measured by Carbon Monoxide (CO) breath levels.
outcome.population: Analysis was considered per Full Analysis Set (FAS) population. FAS population consisted of all randomized participants who had study medication for at least once with assessment data post-dosing.

measure.title: Rate of Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 6
measure.description: Rate of Successful Smoking Cessation at Week 6 was measured by Carbon Monoxide (CO) breath levels.
measure.population: Analysis was considered per Full Analysis Set (FAS) population. FAS population consisted of all randomized participants who had study medication for at least once with assessment data post-dosing.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis considered no treatment difference in the smoking cessation success rate for the active treatment versus its matching placebo.
analysis.estimate_desc: Odds Ratio based on logistic model (adjusted by center)

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis considered no treatment difference in the smoking cessation success rate for the active treatment versus its matching placebo.
analysis.estimate_desc: Odds Ratio based on logistic model (adjusted by center).

outcome.title: Mean Score of Relief of Craving/ Total Withdrawal Symptoms
outcome.description: The evaluation of withdrawal and craving symptoms was carried out every day with the Minnesota Nicotine Withdrawal scale (MNWS). The MNWS total score contains 9 items (urge to smoke; depressed mood; irritability, frustration, or anger; anxiety; difficulty concentrating; restlessness; increased appetite; difficulty going to sleep; difficulty staying asleep). Each item was rated on a 5 grade scale with scores ranging from 0 (best score) to 4 (worst score) i.e. none (score=0), slight (score=1), mild (score=2), moderate (score=3), and severe (score=4). For each symptom at each week, the average score was calculated as the average of the daily scores during that week. The total score was calculated as the sum of the 9 symptoms.
outcome.time_frame: Weekly assessment at Week 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and Week 6
outcome.population: Analysis was carried out per FAS population, which consisted of all randomized subjects who have had study medication for at least once with assessment data post-dosing. Due to drop outs, there was difference in the number of participants analyzed (n) for this outcome measure. Missing values were not imputed.

measure.title: Mean Score of Relief of Craving/ Total Withdrawal Symptoms
measure.description: The evaluation of withdrawal and craving symptoms was carried out every day with the Minnesota Nicotine Withdrawal scale (MNWS). The MNWS total score contains 9 items (urge to smoke; depressed mood; irritability, frustration, or anger; anxiety; difficulty concentrating; restlessness; increased appetite; difficulty going to sleep; difficulty staying asleep). Each item was rated on a 5 grade scale with scores ranging from 0 (best score) to 4 (worst score) i.e. none (score=0), slight (score=1), mild (score=2), moderate (score=3), and severe (score=4). For each symptom at each week, the average score was calculated as the average of the daily scores during that week. The total score was calculated as the sum of the 9 symptoms.
measure.population: Analysis was carried out per FAS population, which consisted of all randomized subjects who have had study medication for at least once with assessment data post-dosing. Due to drop outs, there was difference in the number of participants analyzed (n) for this outcome measure. Missing values were not imputed.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events (AEs), Serious AEs (SAEs), Cardiovascular AEs and Who Discontinued Due to AEs
outcome.description: All AEs and SAEs were reviewed and reported by investigator. AEs were graded on a 3-point scale as Mild, Moderate and Severe.
outcome.time_frame: Weekly assessments from first treatment dose up to 15 days after last treatment dose
outcome.population: Safety Population of this study consists of all randomized participants who have had study medication for at least once.

reported_events.time_frame: All adverse events that occured in time-period from the first administration of product to up to 15 days after the last dosing were recorded
reported_events.desc: Safety evaluation was done for saftey set population. There was one additional subject, randomized to 4mg Placebo, who withdrew consent, but was excluded from the SS population.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: GSK agreements may vary with individual investigators, but will not prohibit any investigator from publishing. GSK supports the publication of results from all centers of a multi-center trial but requests that reports based on single-site data not precede the primary publication of the entire clinical trial.
